title: Solarvest appoints former Sedania CEO Daniel Ruppert as CIO
bodyText:
Solarvest Holdings Bhd has appointed Daniel Bernd Ruppert as its chief investment officer (CIO), formalising his position as part of the group's key senior management team.

Ruppert, 50, brings over 15 years of experience in investment banking and business management.

He is best known for his six-year tenure as CEO of Sedania Innovator Bhd, from January 2018 until his departure at the end of January 2024.

During his time at Sedania, he steered the group into green infrastructure and renewable energy, leading it to record-high profits in 2019 and 2021.

A German national who has lived in Malaysia for two decades, Ruppert will now helm Solarvest's investment strategy.

His responsibilities include asset management, acquisitions and divestments, risk oversight, and strategic capital deployment.

He also leads Solarvest's investment and asset management teams, tasked with sourcing high-quality opportunities and nurturing co-investment partnerships.

Ruppert began his career as an investment banker in London before taking on senior roles across technology-centric industries.

He holds a Master's degree in Business Administration from EBS European Business School in Germany and a Bachelor's degree in Computer Science from James Madison University in the US.

title: DayOne breaks ground on first hyperscale data center in Singapore
bodyText:
- 20MW data center, powered by renewable energy through partnership with Sembcorp Power
- Launched new R&D collaboration with NUS, supporting the Sustainable Tropical Data CenterTestbed Phase 2.0

DayOne has commenced construction on its first hyperscale data center in Singapore, the company announced at a groundbreaking ceremony attended by government and industry leaders on July 25, 2025. The facility, designed with a capacity of 20 megawatts and spanning approximately 40,000 square meters, is expected to become ready for service in 2026.

The data center will support high-density GPU workloads and incorporate both air and liquid cooling systems. According to DayOne, it is anticipated to be the first in Singapore to feature on-site solid oxide fuel cell (SOFC) power generation in a pilot focused on hydrogen-based energy, aiming to diversify energy sources for the sector and contribute to national sustainability goals. The company plans to apply for LEED Platinum and BCA Green Mark Platinum (GMDC:2024) certifications for the new facility.

"This facility marks our commitment to Singapore as both home base and regional hub while highlighting our long-term vision to power Southeast Asia's digital transformation with green infrastructure," said Jamie Khoo, CEO of DayOne Data Centers [pic]. "Our SG1 facility is an important milestone and a contribution to the nation's ambition of being an AI-ready, sustainable digital economy. Backed by strong public-private collaboration, we're building infrastructure that is purpose-built for AI workloads, cloud computing and innovation."

title: Alam Flora launches Glutton electric vacuum litter picker, strengthens urban sustainability efforts
bodyText:
ALAM Flora Sdn Bhd, a subsidiary of Malakoff Corp Bhd, has launched the Glutton electric vacuum litter picker - a fully electric, modern street cleaning machine.

This initiative is aligned with the Circular Economy Master Plan 2025-2035 by the Ministry of Local Government Development (KPKT), particularly under the pillars of green infrastructure and technology integration and forms part of Alam Flora's continuous efforts to strengthen the circular economy agenda in Malaysia.

The launch ceremony was officiated by SWCorp Malaysia chairman Tuan Hee Loy Sian with Alam Flora COO Mohamad Muhazni Mukhtar at Jalan Alor, Bukit Bintang, Kuala Lumpur (KL) yesterday.

"The adoption of green technology such as the Glutton machine not only enhances the efficiency of our urban cleaning operations, but also clearly reflects our commitment and responsibility towards environmental preservation and our continuous efforts to safeguard the well-being of the," Mohamad Muhazni said in a statement.

Designed to clean high-traffic public areas such as Jalan Alor, Masjid India and Dataran Merdeka, KL, the machine offers efficient, low-noise operation ( under 60 decibels) and can run continuously for up to 16 hours on a rechargeable battery.

Key features include a high-powered suction system; 240-litre waste container; ISO5011 dust filter (captures 99.96% of fine particles); LED lights and reverse alarm for safety; and an ergonomic design with joystick control for user comfort.

With a chassis clearance of 20cm from the ground, the machine remains stable and can easily manoeuvre through elevated or uneven urban terrain.

The built-in smart charger enables convenient recharging during operations, while the real-time battery metre helps teams plan and monitor cleaning tasks more effectively.

Its air filter and maintenance panels are designed for quick access without the need for complex tools, saving time and maintenance costs.

The implementation of the Glutton machine is in line with Alam Flora's goal of achieving zero carbon emissions, improving public cleanliness and enhancing overall field productivity.

This initiative is part of Malakoff's business pillar, Malakoff Environmental Solutions' aspiration to focus on environmental management and solutions that are dedicated to serving communities and the planet.

It is also in line with the United Nations Sustainable Development (UN SDG) Goal No 11, which aims to make cities and human settlements inclusive, safe, resilient and sustainable - aligned with Malakoff's overarching purpose of 'Enhancing Life, Enriching Communities'.

In conjunction with Malakoff Group's 50th anniversary this year, the initiative further reflects the Group's continued commitment to driving meaningful impact, not only through operational excellence but also through long-term sustainability and community-building efforts.

title: SARAWAK SHOWCASES GLOBAL CLEAN ENERGY LEADERSHIP AT IEW 2025
bodyText:
Sarawak inaugurated the sixth International Energy Week (IEW) 2025 at the Borneo Convention Centre Kuching (BCCK), reaffirming its pivotal role as a global leader in clean energy innovation amidst the worldwide shift towards sustainable energy.

Held under the theme From Sarawak to the World: Journey to Clean Energy Leadership, IEW 2025 showcased the states ambitious drive to spearhead the energy transition across the Asia-Pacific region and beyond.

In a statement today, Informa Markets Malaysia stated that the prestigious event was officially opened by thePremier of Sarawak, Tan Sri Abang Johari Tun Openg, yesterday.

Among the distinguished guests joining him were Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Energy Transition and Water Transformation, Datuk Seri Fadillah Yusof, and Sarawak Deputy Minister for Energy and Environmental Sustainability, Datuk Dr Hazland Abang Hipni, who is also the IEW 2025 organising chairman.

In his keynote address, Abang Johari reaffirmed Sarawaks unwavering commitment to clean energy.

By harnessing our abundant natural resources and embracing innovation, we aim to reduce carbon emissions and build a sustainable future. Our goal is to meet energy demands without compromising the environment for future generations, he said.

The premier also emphasised the critical importance of human capital development in propelling the clean energy transition.

We need a skilled workforce in this space. This is the platform to produce technologists -- not just for energy, but also for emerging industries like aerospace, he said, noting the broader economic impact of investing in skilled talent.

IEW 2025 attracted over 400 companies and brands from 25 countries, showcasing cutting-edge technologies in renewables, hydrogen, smart grids, energy efficiency, carbon capture, utilisation, and storage (CCUS)and green infrastructure.

With more than 100 exhibition booths, the event was projected to generate US$2.5 million (US$1=RM4.24) in immediate business opportunities, fostering significant economic growth and collaboration.

Sarawaks commitment to clean energy is reflected in its current energy mix, with over 70 per cent of its electricity generated from renewable sources, mainly hydropower.

Major projects such as the Baleh Dam and the Batang Ai floating solar plant, coupled with expanding cross-border grid connectivity with Kalimantan, Brunei, and soon, Singapore, significantly enhance Sarawaks contribution to the ASEAN Power Grid. These developments have rightfully earned Sarawak the title of the Battery of ASEAN.

Beyond hydropower, the state is making substantial strides in advancing its hydrogen economy, includingSoutheast Asias first integrated hydrogen production and refuelling facility.

Strategic partnerships with Japan and South Korea are facilitating vital technology transfer and market expansion, positioning Sarawak at the forefront of the hydrogen revolution.

In parallel, Sarawak is scaling up efforts in CCUS, biomass (including innovative solutions like Napier grass), and waste-to-energy initiatives, further diversifying its clean energy portfolio and reinforcing its dedication to a sustainable future.

To promote an inclusive energy transition, Sarawak is supporting local small and medium enterprises (SMEs) in the oil and gas services and equipment (OGSE) sector, which makes up 85 per cent of the industry.

This support includes promoting access to financing, upskilling programmes, and the adoption of green technologies, ensuring that the benefits of the energy transition are widely shared across the local economy.

IEW 2025 is made possible through the invaluable support of its Platinum, Gold, and Silver sponsors, and key partners such as Business Events Sarawak (BESarawak), which continues to champion impactful and sustainable events.

Official airline and e-hailing partners are also onboard, enhancing the experience for both domestic and international participants.

Through the IEW 2025, Sarawak has conveyed a clear and powerful message to the world: The energy transition is our defining challenge, and Sarawak is ready to take the lead. The state welcomes global collaboration in creating a cleaner, greener, and more inclusive energy future for everyone.

title: Jentayu Sustainables seals landmark deal for 162MW hydropower project in Sabah
bodyText:
Jentayu Sustainables Bhd (JSB) has announced the successful exchange of key agreements for its 162MW run-of-river hydropower project, known as Project Oriole, located in Hulu Sungai Padas, Sipitang, Sabah.

The event, witnessed by Sabah Chief Minister Datuk Seri Panglima Hajiji Noor, marked the signing of the power purchase agreement (PPA) between Oriole Hydro Padas Sdn Bhd (OHP) and Sabah Electricity Sdn Bhd (SESB), as well as the engineering, procurement, construction, and commissioning (EPCC) contract with a consortium led by XD Power Transmission Sdn Bhd.

Slated to begin commercial operations by June 1, 2029 under a 40-year concession, the project will supply renewable energy at a tariff of 31.5 sen/kWh - positioning it among the region's most cost-effective green energy sources.

Developed in partnership with SESB and Yayasan Sabah, Project Oriole is the first new plant-up PPA under the ECoS framework, reinforcing Sabah's energy security and sustainability goals.

JSB executive chairman Datuk Haji Beroz Nikmal Mirdin said, "This milestone underscores our dedication to advancing Sabah's Energy Roadmap 2040 and reflects our confidence in delivering affordable, green infrastructure that benefits both the state and its people."

title: 'Plan to future-proof KL against emerging issues'
bodyText:
KUALA LUMPUR: The Kuala Lumpur Local Plan 2040 (PTKL2040) has been developed not only to address current urban challenges, but also to future-proof the city against emerging issues.

Kuala Lumpur city mayor Datuk Seri Dr Maimunah Mohd Sharif said this included challenges such as climate change, rapid population growth, technological advancements, as well as the increasing demand for smart mobility and resilient green infrastructure.

"PTKL2040 is the primary reference document for determining the direction of Kuala Lumpur's development.

"It is not merely a document, but an action plan that serves as a reference for all stakeholders, aimed at shaping a city that is not only liveable, but also trusted as a destination for investments and growth.

"It addresses physical, economic, social and environmental aspects in a holistic manner and incorporates 12 development principles, including site suitability, basic amenities, utility networks and environmental harmony to ensure that new developments do not burden existing systems, but instead strengthen them," she said at the launch of PTKL2040 yesterday.

Present were Prime Minister Datuk Seri Anwar Ibrahim, Minister in the Prime Minister's Department (Federal Territories) Datuk Seri Dr Zaliha Mustafa, Communications Minister Datuk Fahmi Fadzil and Housing and Local Government Minister Nga Kor Ming.

Also present were Anwar's wife and Bandar Tun Razak member of parliament Datuk Seri Dr Wan Azizah Wan Ismail, and Chief Secretary to the Government, Tan Sri Shamsul Azri Abu Bakar.

Maimunah said in terms of mobility, the plan targeted a 70 per cent public transport usage rate by 2040, supported by the Traffic and Pedestrian and Cycling Masterplans.

She said PTKL2040 also aimed for a minimum target of 20sq m of open space per city resident, amounting to more than 4,700ha.

"From a housing perspective, the plan aims to deliver 305,000 affordable housing units by 2040 to support the development of Madani residences and inclusive communities.

"At the same time, 74 million sq m of commercial floor space is projected to meet the city's economic growth needs and create up to 1.2 million jobs by 2040.

"A total of 139 areas have been identified as having redevelopment potential, with a focus on dilapidated public housing areas.

"Our principle is clear, redevelopment must be resilient, inclusive and based on fair incentives, in line with the principles of social justice under Malaysia Madani."

She said that the plan comprised two volumes, each detailing key components of the city's future direction.

"Volume one focuses on planning controls, including special zones such as heritage areas, affordable housing and redevelopment zones.

"Volume two outlines six strategic goals, including to make Kuala Lumpur an innovative and productive city, inclusive and equitable, green and healthy, climate-smart and low carbon, efficiently mobile, and empowered in urban regeneration, in line with the values of Malaysia Madani."

( END )

title: WORLDWIDE ENTECH CHAMPIONS WASTE-TO-ENERGY INNOVATION IN MALAYSIA
bodyText:
Worldwide Entech Sdn Bhd is taking the lead in promoting Waste-to-Energy (WTE) technology as a pivotal solution in addressing Malaysia€™s growing waste management and climate challenges.

Worldwide Entech general manager Danial Liew Jin Sheon said Malaysia generates over 38,000 tonnes of solid waste daily, with 137 landfills currently operational nationwide.

€œHowever, only 21 are classified as sanitary, while the remaining 126 non-sanitary landfills continue to release untreated methane and leachate into the environment,€ he said in a statement.

Recognising the urgent need for a scalable and integrated solution, Danial said Worldwide Entech, a subsidiary of Worldwide Holdings Berhad, is positioning WTE as a key innovation that reduces waste volume, mitigates climate impact, and contributes to national energy production.

€œWTE technology offers a safe, clean method to convert residual, non-recyclable waste into electricity through controlled combustion.

€œOne tonne of waste processed in a WTE facility can reduce greenhouse gas emissions, particularly methane, which is 25 times more potent than carbon dioxide,€ Danial said.

He noted that as part of supporting the 12th Malaysia Plan and the national target of achieving a 40 per cent recycling rate by 2025, the company also offers full-spectrum waste infrastructure solutions.

€œThis includes the design, construction, operation, and aftercare of sanitary landfills; leachate treatment plants to prevent groundwater contamination; landfill gas (LFG) recovery systems that reduce methane emissions and produce energy.

€œIt also includes rehabilitation of old dumpsites to meet environmental safety standards and waste transfer stations that improve efficiency and reduce emissions in logistics,€ he said.

Despite its environmental benefits, Danial said WTE faces public misconceptions equating it to pollution-heavy incineration, a key barrier to broader public acceptance and policy acceleration.

To address this, Danial said Worldwide Entech is ramping up community engagement, environmental transparency, and public education to reshape perceptions of modern waste solutions.

To overcome this challenge, Danial said Worldwide Entech is intensifying community engagement, environmental transparency, and public education efforts to reshape how Malaysians view modern waste solutions.

€œWorldwide Entech is helping redefine waste, not as a burden, but as a sustainable resource. By reimagining waste management through an integrated, forward-thinking lens, the company is laying the foundation for a more climate-resilient future.

€œThe modern WTE process is equipped with robust emission controls that comply with international standards. The emphasis on transparency and data reporting allows stakeholders to see the measurable benefits of WTE, from reduced landfill dependency to energy recovery.

Following Malaysia€™s participation in Expo 2025 Osaka, Danial added that the focus on sustainability leadership and circular economy innovation reinforces how technologies like WTE could position the country as a regional front-runner in green infrastructure and environmental transformation.

title: SABAH ALLOCATED RM11.15 MILLION FOR GREEN LANDSCAPE PROGRAMMES THIS YEAR - DR JOACHIM
bodyText:
The government has allocated RM11.15 million for the implementation of various landscape programmes and projects in Sabah this year, said Deputy Chief Minister II Datuk Seri Dr Joachim Gunsalam.

He said the allocation, provided by the federal and state governments, will be distributed to all local government authorities (PBT) in Sabah to develop and upgrade green infrastructure for the well-being of the people.

According to Joachim, who is also the Sabah Minister of Local Government and Housing, the allocation is in line with the Sabah landscape development planning initiative which emphasises the importance of sustainability, environmental beauty and ecological balance in urban and rural development.

"I understand the need for allocations for PBTs to develop and upgrade green infrastructure facilities for the well-being of the local community," he said in his special address in conjunction with the "I P.L.A.N.T." Programme here, today.

The text of the speech was read out by  Sabah Assistant Minister of Local Government and Housing Datuk Isnin Aliasnih

The €œI P.L.A.N.T.€ programme --  Inisiatif Penghijauan Lestari, Aspirasi Negeri Taman Terindah - Sustainable Greening Initiative, Aspiration of the Most Beautiful Park State -- is one of the steps taken by the State Local Government and Housing Ministry to strengthen the sustainability of Sabah's landscape through close collaboration with the PBTs.

<p data-end="486" data-start="57">He said that as of December last year, a total of 331,151 trees had been planted under the programme since its launch in 2020.

<p data-end="915" data-start="488">In addition to tree planting, Dr Joachim said the ministry also organised various awareness and education programmes.

<p data-end="915" data-start="488">These include the Green Resolution Workshop, PBT tours to promote green practices at the grassroots level, and community-driven initiatives such as Community Gardens and Sustainable Partners, which are aimed at encouraging direct community involvement in environmental conservation.

He said one of the principles emphasised by the ministry is the promotion of a sustainable circular economy, which involves the efficient use of resources, reducing the carbon footprint, advancing green technology, and preserving the environment.

<p data-end="1384" data-start="917">The ministry, he said, also collaborates with the federal government on various initiatives, such as the Sustainable Community Agenda, the Low Carbon Schools project, and the implementation of the SDG Roadmap and Voluntary Local Review in five selected local authorities.

<p data-end="1384" data-start="917">These efforts are part of an integrated strategy to transform Sabah into the most beautiful garden state, with a focus on enhancing economic, social, and environmental aspects, he added.

<p data-end="1384" data-start="917"> 

<p data-end="1384" data-start="917">-- BERNAMA

title: KOTA MADANI TENDERS TO OPEN SOON
bodyText:
SHAREN KAUR

bt@nst.com.my

PUTRAJAYA: PUTRAJAYA Holdings Sdn Bhd is set to launch the tender process for the RM4 billion Kota Madani urban development in Precinct 19, Putrajaya, in the third quarter of this year, marking a key step forward in Malaysia's next-generation city-building agenda.

Putrajaya Corp president Datuk Fadlun Mak Ujud told Business Times that the 41.28ha development will be carried out under a build, lease, maintain and transfer (BLMT) model, framing it as a long-term, asset-backed initiative aligned with national urban development goals.

He said the project's estimated development cost stands at RM4 billion, although the final figure will be confirmed once implementation begins.

"This is a government housing project. We're not selling the units, but leasing options may be considered if there is demand," Fadlun added.

He emphasised that Kota Madani goes far beyond traditional residential development, describing it as a high-impact, strategic initiative designed to reinforce Putrajaya's position as a world-class, people-centric city under the government's Madani framework.

Fadlun said Putrajaya Holdings was appointed as the master developer of Kota Madani based on its extensive experience and proven track record.

He said a transparent open bidding process will be launched in the coming months, inviting qualified contractors and service providers to participate.

Contract awards will be merit-based, with a strong emphasis on technical capability, integration of sustainable solutions and alignment with the township's smart city and community-focused vision.

The groundbreaking for Kota Madani is scheduled for tomorrow, kicking off a transformative urban initiative aimed at elevating the standard of living in Malaysia's administrative capital.

Kota Madani will offer 10,000 high-density vertical housing units built in three phases, accommodating up to 35,000 residents upon full completion. It will also feature artificial intelligence-driven systems, advanced digital infrastructure and a suite of green mobility options to support a low-carbon lifestyle.

The project's first phase (1A and 1B), which comprises 3,000 high-density residential units and an eight-storey school, is targeted for completion by end of 2027.

Kota Madani is designed to serve as a model township under the government's Madani framework, integrating smart technologies, green infrastructure, energy-efficient systems and essential public services into a cohesive urban ecosystem.

Key components of the township will include government quarters, healthcare facilities, schools, financial institutions and green mobility solutions, all within walkable, self-contained residential precincts, according to Malaysian Institute of Planners president Datin Mazrina Abdul Khalid.

The township is anchored on the CHASE vision (Clean, Healthy, Advanced, Safe and Eco-friendly), a policy framework designed to transform Federal Territories into liveable, sustainable cities.

This vision emphasises environmentally responsible practices, digital integration and inclusive infrastructure as foundations for improved urban quality of life.

Mazrina said the township's masterplan draws inspiration from Malaysia's architectural heritage, merging cultural identity with modern urban design to create a distinctive living environment.

"Kota Madani goes beyond conventional housing. It is a forward-looking model for smart, sustainable, and inclusive development," she said.

Mazrina said complementing the residential areas are critical amenities such as a health clinic, fire station, police station and a mosque.

She noted that the project will feature green elements, including energy-efficient initiatives.

With its strong policy alignment, future-ready design and strategic execution model, Kota Madani is poised to become a benchmark for urban development not only in Putrajaya, but nationwide.

title: Explained: The RM4b Kota Madani megaproject set to transform Putrajaya's landscape
bodyText:
KUALA LUMPUR, June 27 -- Imagine a living, thriving pedestrianised smart city roughly the size of 57 football fields equipped with various public amenities and green spaces for 35,000 people in the near future.

Finding it difficult to visualise?

Fret not, you don't need to look any further since one is currently being developed in the nation's administrative capital of Putrajaya.

What is Kota Madani?

Kota Madani or Madani City is a RM4 billion megaproject currently undertaken by the Malaysian government and Perbadanan Putrajaya.

The 102-acre megaproject will be developed by Putrajaya Holdings Sdn Bhd through a public-private partnership model based on the build, lease, maintain and transfer (BLMT) concept, without involving any government allocation in the initial phase.

Key components of the township will include 10,000 units of vertically built government quarters for approximately 35,000 civil servants and their families; financial institutions, eateries, community halls, bazaar sites, offices and commercial lots, all within walkable, self-contained residential precincts.

There will also be built-in public amenities such as a police and fire station, a house of worship, healthcare facilities, football fields, parks, schools, and institutions for Technical and Vocational Education and Training (TVET), a petrol station and a viewing platform overlooking Putrajaya Lake.

Designed to serve as a model township under the government's Madani framework, Kota Madani will integrate smart technologies, green infrastructure, energy-efficient systems, and essential public services into one cohesive urban ecosystem.

Where is it located?

Kota Madani will be situated along Lebuh Wadi Ehsan and Persiaran Selatan in Presint 19, Putrajaya.

It spans about 0.8 per cent of Putrajaya's total land area.

When is it going to be liveable?

According to the planned timeline, the megaproject's first phase - which comprises 3,000 residential units - is targeted for completion by the end of 2027.

The second phase - which includes the remaining 7,000 residential units and other public amenities - is targeted for completion by the end of 2028.

The entire project is slated for full completion within seven years or by 2032.

Who are the intended dwellers of Kota Madani?

Civil servants and government pensioners.

Why another megaproject?

Kota Madani and its eventual development emerged after the federal government saw the urgency to provide sufficient and affordable, high-quality housing needs to civil servants.

Federal Territories Minister Datuk Seri Dr Zaliha Mustafa was quoted recently as saying there is a current backlog of more than 17,000 unfulfilled applications for government quarters placement.

The township's development also demonstrates the government's commitment to support the growth of smart and sustainable cities.

How is Kota Madani different from other township developments?

With over seven percent of its total area developed as green spaces, Kota Madani is anchored upon the CHASE City vision (clean, healthy, advanced, safe and eco-friendly) - a policy framework designed to transform Malaysia's federal territories into liveable, sustainable cities.

The township also boasts 2.8km of support and mobility infrastructures, with a heavy emphasis on pedestrian accessibility and walkability.

Green and solar roofing, along with vertical gardens, will also be incorporated into the architecture of each block of the government quarters, providing natural insulation and an improved quality of life.

Among its unique features is the inclusion of vertical schools - schools with six or more storeys that is typically higher than a traditional horizontal school - built in response to urbanisation and land scarcity.

According to the developer, the three vertical schools - two primary and one secondary - with a total of 54 classrooms are designed to provide universal access to roofed pedestrian walkways between residential units and the schools.

Conceptualised as a smart city, technologies such as intelligent traffic systems, solar pathways, automated waste disposal system, closed-circuit surveillance system, disaster warning system and community WiFi access will be integrated into its development.

Most importantly, the township will be supported by the Local Urban Observatory system which utilises technologies such as artificial intelligence (AI), big data and Internet of Things (IoT) to drive real-time monitoring of facilities, electricity usage, water quality, waste management and security.

There will also be built-in public amenities such as a police and fire station, a house of worship, healthcare facilities, football fields, parks, schools, and institutions for Technical and Vocational Education and Training (TVET), a petrol station and a viewing platform overlooking Putrajaya Lake. title: City & Country: Cover Story: The birth of a new smart city
bodyText:
The northern part of Miri, near the mouth of the Baram River, will soon be home to the estimated RM5 billion Kenyalang Smart City (KSC) integrated development by Imasa Dinasti Sdn Bhd, a subsidiary of TAK Group of Companies. Named after the hornbill, the official bird of Sarawak, this catalytic development is set to boost the stateâ s economic growth and bring in investment and business opportunities.

Teo Ah Khing, founder and chairman of TAK Group, is a proud Sarawakian with more than 30 years of experience in architecture and urban design. He will lead the team in realising the KSC master plan, which will offer medical, commercial, leisure and educational facilities for future generations of Malaysians, as well as interested parties from around the globe.

Teo, who spent many years plying his trade abroad, has decided to contribute to the economic development of Sarawak, a place he holds close to his heart. Born in Kuching, but grew up in Miri, he is the youngest of 10 siblings. Both his father, a fisherman, and his mother, a homemaker, were from Putian in China.

Teo studied architecture at the University of New South Wales in Sydney, Australia, graduating with a Bachelor of Architecture (Honours) in 1986. He then worked for one year with John Andrews, a prolific and internationally known Australian architect who had made a name for himself with projects in the US and Canada.

â They handled big projects in Australia. I got experience doing the whole infrastructure â " roads, drains and urban design,â he recalls.

Andrews advised him to go to Harvard University if he wanted to go further in urban design. So, Teo applied for the Master of Architecture in Urban Design at the university. His application was accepted in 1987. At Harvard, he learnt everything about the built environment, from basic drainage to weather, flooding, traffic flow and beyond.

After graduating from Harvard in 1989, he was headhunted and moved to Tokyo, Japan, to work for Nikken Sekkei Ltd. He worked there for four years and helped to open the firmâ s Singapore office.

In 1993, he ventured out on his own at the age of 33 to start Teo A. Khing Design Consultants. One of his first clients was DBSLand, a subsidiary of DBS Bank. He worked in the Asean region in countries such as Vietnam, Thailand, Malaysia and Indonesia.

Teo and his team have designed master plans for various projects, including Putrajaya, the Federal Administrative Centre in Kuching and the Port of Tanjung Pelepas in Johor Bahru. Overseas, he was involved in the masterplans for Dubaiâ s Palm Deira, Palm Jebel Ali, Madinat Al Arab, the Meydan Racecourse & Grandstand and Meydan City, which was designed around the racecourse.

While it may seem that he only takes on big projects, Teo says, â Building big is not an intention, like I want to build big. It is a comprehensive understanding of the entire project. Like a general practitioner understands the human body, a specialist understands the function of a specific organ and how to treat it.

â In a built environment, architects are very specific about certain needs. It can be a house or a condominium. But for an urban designer, he is first a specialist, but he is also a generalist. Urban design is not about being big, it is about being complete.â

A smart city development

Teoâ s body of work had prepared him to design the KSC master plan. Situated on 543 acres of land, almost similar to the size of Desa ParkCity in Kuala Lumpur and about half the size of Bandar Utama in Selangor, the new smart city will be built in three phases.

Phase 1 will be built between 2025 and 2028. It will comprise the Fudan University Joint Research Center for Innovative Drug Development in Integrated Chinese and Western Medicine, including a residential component; Kenyalang Convention & Exhibition Centre (KCEC); Nexus Hotel & Shopping Mall; the commercial KCEC Square and accommodation at KSC Lagoon Park, which targets the tourism sector.

Phase 2 will be developed between 2027 and 2035, with the establishment of Fudan Healthcare City and Fudan University SEA Campus. There will also be the AI & Technology Centre, KCEC Plaza, KCEC Avenue, Lagoon Park, Lagoon Villas and a solar farm.

Phase 3, scheduled from 2030 to 2038, will feature Kenyalang Square, a clean energy industrial park, data centres and Kenyalang Lake.

According to Teo, the development of the KSC land, which is owned by Imasa Dinasti, will be financed through a hybrid funding model comprising private investments, internal capital and targeted government funding injections. â This multi-stream approach ensures financial resilience while enabling impactful, long-term development,â he says.

One of the land challenges Teo and his team have to deal with is the areaâ s susceptibility to flooding. To counter this, they carved out 200 acres of retention and holding ponds to contain and hold all forms of excess water from the rain and sea before safely releasing the water when the time is right.

The team did a 100-year forecast on tidal behaviour and rainfall to ensure the master planâ s designs and infrastructure will be able to withstand such incidents. According to Teo, people normally conduct a 50-year study. â I donâ t want investors who invest billions of dollars to come in and later have to use a boat to get to work,â he smiles.

Teo reveals that one of the key components of KSC â " Fudan University Joint Research Center for Innovative Drug Development in Integrated Chinese and Western Medicine â " got off to a good start on June 11 with the signing of an agreement between Imasa Dinasti and Fudan University to jointly establish the centre.

He says, â This university is considered Ivy League in China. It immediately wanted to set up the research institute. So, the local government offered the Miri old council building downtown to Fudan for its administrative office and classrooms for its certificate courses.

â Hopefully, by the end of this year or before Chinese New Year, we can launch the Fudan programme in Southeast Asia. The only Fudan University Joint Research Center for Innovative Drug Development in Integrated Chinese and Western Medicine will be in Miri.â

The centre will be its flagship biomedical facility, and a strategic partnership has been set up between Fudan University, Imasa Dinasti and the Sarawak Biodiversity Centre for it to be a regional hub for integrative medicine. It will integrate research, education, training and product commercialisation. The campus will have three blocks of 2-storey research and teaching facilities, with a capacity of 200 researchers and PhD students.

There are plans for specialised laboratories for pharmaceutical sciences, traditional medicine, biotechnology, biodiversity and ethnobotany, as well as facilities for phytochemical analysis, bioassays, molecular biology and tissue culture.

Moreover, it will have training infrastructure with classrooms, lecture halls, teaching labs and demonstration gardens. It will also have specimen handling and storage facilities, a specialised showroom and a visitorsâ interpretation gallery to engage with stakeholders and the community.

In addition to the centre, a purpose-built accommodation called The One KSC Residence Serviced Apartment and Fudan House will also be built. It will house medical doctors, researchers, healthcare professionals and visiting academics.

The serviced apartments will have modern conveniences and co-living suites with flexible layouts to cater for short-term stays and long-term residence. The project, which will have an estimated gross development value (GDV) of RM130 million, will be launched in 4Q2025. The selling price has not been finalised.

â This mixed-use module promotes synergy between academia, commerce and the community, ensuring that innovation spills beyond the labs into everyday life,â says Teo.

Another component to be built concurrently with the research centre is the KCEC.

â The Sarawak government is expected to play a strategic role through equity participation in selected catalytic components under Phase 1, namely the KCEC and the Nexus Hotel & Shopping Mall. These partnerships underscore the stateâ s commitment to advancing public-private collaboration in urban innovation,â he says.

The KCEC is positioned as an integrated transit-oriented development (TOD) that embodies the principles of sustainable urbanism, human-centric design and intelligent architecture, to deliver a synergised business event ecosystem with a walkable, connected and high-performance area. It will comprise a convention and exhibition hall, business hotel, retail galleria, performance art centre, Sarawak Heritage & Cultural Museum and a technology centre gallery â " all within a 300m radius.

Anchored by a proposed inter-region bus terminal, this will form a central hub of a multi-nodal transport network, supporting regional accessibility and urban densification. Teo explains that the terminal will possibly foster cross-border business events, tourism and talent exchange.

â [The terminal] will be based on a PPP [publicâ "private partnership] model, where the government will fund it and the private sector will drive it to completion. The government will be anticipated to run the operations and maintenance. These are considered public infrastructure.

â This urban design framework is further reinforced through axial visual corridors and green linkages, notably the linear spine known as the Knowledge Axis, which links the Fudan University main campus with Kenyalang Lake, encouraging civic vitality and socio-academic exchange.â

He explains that the KCEC will be built sustainably using prefabricated construction methods to reduce its carbon footprint and enhance building efficiency. Green materials will be used to maximise life-cycle performance, while solar roofing and smart energy systems will contribute to renewable energy use. The design also includes rainwater harvesting infrastructure, expanded shaded zones, urban greening and thermal comfort strategies to improve environmental resilience and occupant well-being.

â KCEC is more than a venue â " it is a dynamic engine for knowledge exchange, creative economy and smart living reflecting a new paradigm of resilient, connected and human-scaled urbanism in East Malaysia. Through its urban-intelligent integration, it sets a benchmark for future-ready city making in the region and beyond,â says Teo.

Commercial activities will be centred at KCEC Square, located adjacent to Fudan University Joint Research Center for Innovative Drug Development in Integrated Chinese and Western Medicine, that will serve as a vibrant commercial precinct. It will comprise shopoffices, pedestrian-priority streets and shaded colonnades to foster social interaction in climate comfort and integration with smart mobility modes such as e-scooters, bike-sharing docks and electric vehicle (EV) drop-off bays. With an estimated GDV of RM70 million, it is scheduled for launch in 4Q2025. The details will be revealed at a later date.

Lastly, tourism and accommodation will be anchored at KSC Lagoon Park, the smart cityâ s dedicated leisure and tourism hub. At its heart will be a nine-acre waterbody surrounded by smart resort villas equipped with Internet of Things-enabled energy and security systems. The precinct will also feature mixed-use podiums combining F&B outlets, retail spaces and co-living suites; hotels and serviced apartments to support tourists and medical visitors; and public waterfront plazas and boardwalks designed for recreation and community engagement.

â This waterfront district is an example of blue-green infrastructure, blending ecological water management with placemaking and wellness-focused tourism. The Lagoon also functions as a climate buffer, enhancing biodiversity and passive cooling within the urban core,â says Teo.

Phase 2 and 3 highlights

While the details of the Phase 2 and 3 components are still being planned, Teo is able to provide a glimpse into what some components have to offer. For Phase 2, he highlights Fudan Healthcare City, Fudan University SEA Campus and the solar farm.

He explains that the future healthcare facility will provide an ecosystem for medical care and senior living, while promoting medical tourism. The healthcare city will feature the doughnut-shaped Fudan Huashan Specialist Hospital, which will offer a 450-bed tertiary medical facility with an oncology specialisation, elder care complex, a special wards block and premier patient hotel for high-care and medical tourism, and a medical education and teaching centre.

The Fudan Huashan Specialist Hospital will incorporate Medical Technology 6.0, a proprietary system developed under Fudan IP to help provide AI-assisted diagnostics and treatment planning, autonomous medicine delivery and telehealth robotics and precision patient monitoring, and cloud-integrated electronic medical records.

â The Fudan Huashan Specialist Hospital is a keystone infrastructure in KSCâ s ambition to become a healthcare innovation cluster. It creates a transdisciplinary synergy between education, clinical application, wellness tourism and biotechnology incubation,â says Teo.

He explains that the design of the healthcare city will help promote recovery and a sense of well-being. It will have a ground level public plaza with a therapeutic urban garden, a central plaza for community engagement, wellness education and health outreach as well as commercial activities like F&B outlets, pharmacies and health-related retail.

The podium level will have a patient-centric garden with green recovery terraces, physiotherapy pathways and sensory gardens in a semi-private area. It will also provide wellness cafÃ©s, rehabilitation zones and resting courtyards for families and caretakers.

In a first, the Fudan University SEA Campus will be established in KSC. It will be the first international campus of a top-tier Chinese university â " top three in China, No 1 in healthcare and medical sciences and No 36 globally. Teo reveals its historical significance as the Chinese government endorses and supports Fudan University to establish a fully fledged postgraduate and research-oriented branch outside of China.

â Positioned as one of the main anchors of KSC, the university functions as a driver of the K-economy, bio-economy and healthcare innovation. Through its strategic partnership with the Sarawak government and FIIM Education (Malaysia), a subsidiary of TAK Group, the university is envisioned to catalyse regional talent development, high-value innovation and cross-border academic exchange,â he says.

He adds that the university will train students in both Western and traditional medicine, which will help alleviate the shortage of doctors in the state.

â The Fudan University SEA Campus is more than an academic institution. It is a city-building instrument shaping the knowledge, health and innovation economy of Miri, Sarawak, and the wider Asean region,â says Teo.

To provide renewable energy to KSC, a solar farm is planned. It will have a 200MW facility to provide energy resilience for mission-critical facilities like hospitals and data centres. It will be integrated with smart metering, building-integrated photovoltaics and district energy management platforms as well as provide real-time carbon monitoring and ESG performance dashboards.

â This sustainable energy loop supports Sarawakâ s green economic transition, while enhancing energy security and cost competitiveness for investors and residents alike,â he says.

As for Phase 3, the only details provided are for the data centre, which supports KSCâ s goal of being a data-driven intelligent city. Phase 1 of the data centre component will deliver 50MW of Tier III+ capacity and will support healthcare analytics, university research and fintech and governance systems.

Collaboration strategies

Besides the physical components, KSC will offer technologically advanced services and products, as well as various other conveniences that will enhance lifestyles and quality of life. Moreover, support from neighbour Brunei will benefit the smart city.

â Brunei has an undersea cable and it has agreed to open up. The cableâ s high-speed network will come right through Miri to KSC â " zero lag time,â says Teo.

He reveals that Sungai Tujuh on the border of Brunei and Sarawak will become a land port. Discussions have been made with Bruneiâ s Muara Port Company Sdn Bhd, which controls the operations at Muara Port, to allow cargo to be offloaded there before being transported to KSC.

Teo and his team are busy engaging with various interested parties, both local and international, and they are confident KSCâ s offerings will be realised. He highlights how Sarawakâ s government is stable and fully committed to elevating the stateâ s economic level to be an attractive investment destination.

Moreover, Brunei is looking to participate in KSCâ s growth and development, allowing for cross-border partnerships and business relationships that will be a win-win for both countries. The fact that Miri is only a five-hour flight to countries like India, China, Japan, South Korea, the Philippines, Thailand, Singapore and Indonesia, with a total population of 3.8 billion, is another opportunity.

Teo is currently in discussions with other Malaysian developers regarding their potential participation in the development of KSC, although no formal agreements have been confirmed yet. Nevertheless, he says several people have offered to buy property in KSC even before anything is built or confirmed.

With so much at stake, Teo is mindful of the objective of KSC. â Weâ re here to build a city, build a hometown and build a legacy. Itâ s not about how many dollars and cents youâ ll make. Of course, we donâ t want to lose money because the government puts a lot of trust in us. Once value is established, the brand is there, people will come,â he says.

â The integrated mixed-use components of KSC serve as urban amplifiers â " intensifying land use efficiency, economic productivity and social interaction across the cityâ s innovation landscape. By embedding TOD strategies, green infrastructure and intelligent systems into every district, KSC is positioned as a next-generation smart city model, not only for Sarawak but for Southeast Asia at large.â

title: Malaysia, South Korea strengthen cooperation in construction technology
bodyText:
MALAYSIA and South Korea are strengthening ties in infrastructure development via future collaboration.

At the Korea-Malaysia Road & Construction Technology Cooperation Seminar on April 15, Works Minister Datuk Seri Alexander Nanta Linggi said the bilateral relationship between the two nations, established on Feb 23, 1960, has flourished for 65 years.

The seminar, jointly organised by the Korea University in Malaysia, the Works Ministry and the International Contractors Association of Korea, brought together leaders and innovators from both countries to explore advancements in construction technology.

Historically, South Korean companies have left several marks on Malaysia's skyline with projects such as the Penang Bridge and Petronas Twin Towers.

Nanta mentioned the meeting held with Korea's Land, Infrastructure and Transport Minister Park Sung-woo last November, which laid the groundwork for this seminar and a proposed memorandum of understanding (MOU) on infrastructure cooperation.

He also pointed to Malaysia's National Construction Policy 2030 as a key driver in transforming the country's construction landscape.

"This policy aims to integrate technology into work processes and business culture - a game changer for Malaysia's construction sector," he said.

Recognising South Korea's global leadership in smart highways and green infrastructure, he was optimistic about future cooperation.

The event gathered over 130 participants, including Malaysian government officials and Korean infrastructure experts.

The seminar, a follow-up to last year's ministerial talks, featured discussions on advanced road and construction technologies, with presentations from the Korea Agency for Infrastructure Technology Advancement (KAIA), Korea Expressway Corp (KEC), Korea Institute of Civil Engineering and Building Technology (KICT) and others, alongside insights from Lembaga Lebuhraya Malaysia, Public Works Department's Centre of Excellence in Engineering & Technology (CREaTE) and the Construction Industry Development Board Malaysia (CIDB).

title: CHINA, AUSTRALIA AMONG SEVEN NATIONS IN BILATERAL TALKS WITH ANWAR
bodyText:
Prime Minister Datuk Seri Anwar Ibrahim today held a series of bilateral meetings with senior leaders and representatives from seven countries and international entities, on the sidelines of the 58th ASEAN Foreign Ministers Meeting (AMM) and related meetings currently taking place here.

The meetings, held at the Prime Ministers Office, involved China, Australia, Pakistan, Turkiye, Palestine, the United Kingdom (UK)and the European Union.

In his meeting with Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi, Anwar said both sides discussed various aspects of MalaysiaChina ties, which continues to be strengthened following President Xi Jinpings state visit to Malaysia in April, during which 31 memoranda of understanding and agreements were signed.

China has remained Malaysias largest trading partner for 16 consecutive years, with total trade reaching US$106 billion in 2024.We also explored efforts to narrow the trade gap and expand cooperation in the port, liquefied natural gas (LNG), water, digital economy, and green technology sectors, he said in a statement issued to Bernama and RTM.

Anwar also expressed appreciation for Chinas support of ASEANs Five-Point Consensus regarding the situation in Myanmar and reiterated the importance of a peaceful resolution to the South China Sea issue, in line with international law, including the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS).

During his meeting with Australian Foreign Minister Penny Wong, Anwar said Malaysia and Australia continued discussions towards strengthening bilateral relations, which have been established since 1957.

I welcome the interest of Australian investors in the smart manufacturing, digital economy, artificial intelligence and renewable energy sectors.

Australia has also been invited to participate in the Malaysia International Halal Showcase (MIHAS) this September, in line with the halal economys vast potential as a driver of future cooperation, he said.

Anwar also said that education remains one of the key pillars of MalaysiaAustralia relations, and both countries are expected to sign a new memorandum of understanding (MoU) at the Annual Leaders Meeting in October.

The MoU will cover areas including Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM), Technical and Vocational Education and Training (TVET), curriculum developmentand student exchange programmes.

I also appreciate Australias support in enhancing local vaccine capability through training and research funding amounting to AU$500,000, said Anwar.

The prime minister also said he looks forward to the official visit of Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese to Malaysia in October, which is expected to open a new chapter in bilateral relations based on trust, shared values and aspirations for a more peaceful and prosperous Indo-Pacific.

In a meeting with Pakistans Deputy Prime Minister and Foreign Minister Mohammad Ishaq Dar, Anwar said discussions revolvedaround the upcoming official visit of Pakistan Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif to Malaysia, during which several Memoranda of Understanding (MoUs) are expected to be signed.

Alhamdulillah, MalaysiaPakistan trade value rose by over 25 per cent last year to US$1.76 billion. Both sides agreed to finalise the MalaysiaPakistan Closer Economic Partnership Agreement (MPCEPA), and also discussed ways to expand halal meat exports from Pakistan, with a focus on price competitiveness, Anwar said.

The two leaders also explored potential cooperation in agriculture, particularly in rice trade.

During the half-hour meeting, Anwar and Mohammad Ishaq Dar also exchanged views on regional and global developments, including ASEANPakistan relations and the issue of Jammu and Kashmir.

Malaysia remains committed to a peaceful resolution through dialogue in accordance with relevant United Nations Security Council resolutions. We also encourage deeper engagement between Pakistan and ASEAN moving forward, Anwar added.

Anwar also received a courtesy call from Turkish Foreign Minister Hakan Fidan and his delegation, which reaffirmed the shared commitment to strengthening bilateral ties to a more strategic level.

The meeting also discussed the implementation of the High-Level Strategic Cooperation Council (HLSC) and the Joint Committee Meeting (JCM) between the two foreign ministries key platforms to resolve pending matters and explore new avenues for cooperation.

According to Anwar, Turkiye is currently Malaysias third-largest trading partner in West Asia, and Malaysia is keen to encourage further investments in strategic sectors such as semiconductors, pharmaceuticals, digital and green economy, artificial intelligence (AI)and aerospace.

I also appreciate Turkiyes involvement in Malaysias defence industry and its participation in the Langkawi International Maritime and Aerospace Exhibition (LIMA) 2025. We are also expecting the signing of a defence cooperation MoU and further streamlining of defence equipment procurement between both governments, he said.

Meanwhile, Anwar's meeting with United Kingdom (UK) Foreign Secretary David Lammy focused on enhancing cooperation across various areas, including investment, energy transition, education, climate change, defence, digitalisation and AI.

I received this courtesy call in the spirit of strengthening bilateral relations, which were elevated to a Strategic Partnership following my meeting with UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer in January.

I also welcome increased UK investments, particularly in the semiconductor and green infrastructure sectors, through the Global Industrial Strategy (GIS), and I expressed appreciation for the UKs active role as an ASEAN Dialogue Partner, especially in supporting humanitarian efforts in Myanmar and urging a ceasefire along with the implementation of the Five-Point Consensus (5PC), Anwar said.

-- BERNAMA

title: How tariffs and taxes could derail Malaysia's climate ambitions - Mogesh Sababathy
bodyText:
Kuala Lampur, July 16 -- At a time when Malaysia must accelerate its climate transition, can we afford foreign and domestic policy shocks that destabilize our climate finance and green technology agenda?

The recent announcement by the US President Donald Trump to impose a sweeping 25 per cent tariff on "any and all Malaysian products" starting August 1, 2025, has jolted Malaysia's economy and potentially, its entire energy transition trajectory. This move, posted not only threatens our US$80 billion annual trade relationship with the US, but risks undercutting the financial and industrial scaffolding needed to meet our net-zero ambitions by 2050.

For a country that has pledged a 45 per cent reduction in carbon intensity by 2030, this is not just an economic setback but also a stress test of our climate governance, resilience, and readiness.

The potential impact is immense. Sectors like electrical and electronics (E&E) which comprise nearly 40 per cent of our exports stand particularly exposed. With the Green Technology Master Plan relying heavily on E&E to drive decarbonised manufacturing, this development places our climate-linked industrial strategy in jeopardy.

At the same time, Malaysia's expanded Sales and Service Tax (SST) which came into effect July 1, 2025 adds pressure from within. Over 4,800 previously exempt items, including industrial equipment and low-emission machinery, are now taxed at 8 per cent, up from the previous 6 per cent. While the SST expansion is projected to yield RM3 billion in additional revenue, its timing couldn't be worse. The Federation of Malaysian Manufacturers (FMM) warns that these cascading tax burdens will inflate costs, shrink margins, and deter future investment especially in capital-intensive green infrastructure.

The National Energy Transition Roadmap (NETR), launched in 2023, sets ambitious targets: increasing renewable energy in the national mix to 70 per cent by 2050, developing CCUS (Carbon Capture, Utilisation & Storage), and attracting RM435 billion in investment. But these goals rely on a strong private sector, foreign direct investment, and investor confidence.

Reduced export earnings due to tariffs, paired with higher domestic operating costs from the SST, could stall clean energy adoption, battery storage scaling, and smart grid investments. Small and medium green-tech enterprises already navigating tight financing margins may pivot to survival mode, postponing R&D or abandoning green upgrades entirely.

This fiscal constriction directly threatens the creation of 23,000 green jobs forecasted under NETR, and it risks reducing Malaysia's contribution to global clean energy supply chains at a time when demand is rising.

On the other hand, Malaysia's Voluntary Carbon Market (VCM), launched via the Bursa Carbon Exchange (BCX) in late 2022, was one of Southeast Asia's most promising climate finance innovations. With a projected market value of US$237 million by 2030, it was expected to fund reforestation, conservation, and industrial decarbonisation projects.

However, the VCM and the upcoming carbon tax and Emissions Trading Scheme (ETS) under the National Climate Change Bill (Ruupin) are all sensitive to macroeconomic conditions. Historically, economic downturns or trade disruptions often lead governments to delay carbon pricing reforms in the name of economic recovery. Malaysia is no exception.

Unless insulated, our carbon governance mechanisms may stall or regress under fiscal and political pressure just when they're needed to drive long-term decarbonisation and attract green capital.

Climate change disproportionately affects the poorest and most vulnerable communities in Malaysia from coastal erosion in Sabah to urban flooding in KL. But so too will economic instability.

Tariff-related export losses could result in job cuts in key industrial areas, while SST inflation will raise living costs. When people are forced to choose between short-term survival and long-term sustainability, the environment always loses.

Without targeted support, our vision of a "just transition" risks becoming rhetorical. The Ruupin framework, which emphasizes equity and protection for vulnerable populations, must be backed by resilient fiscal policy and progressive social safety nets not sacrificed in budget cuts driven by external shocks.

In this regard, what can Malaysia do? Firstly, Malaysia must demand clarity on the tariff scope and seek exclusions for clean technology, solar components, and environmental goods, aligning with WTO environmental exceptions.

Next, allocate funds from the new SST intake to fund VCM capacity-building, CCUS pilots, and green job retraining programs. SST exemptions or rebates for low-emission equipment, energy-efficient machinery, and carbon audit services must also be provided to incentivise clean industrial investments.

Also, as the Chair of Asean this year, we also have an upper hand in using this moment to lead within Asean, pushing for regional carbon border adjustments and green mutual recognition agreements that support decarbonised exports.

Lastly, fast-track funding for climate policy education, especially in carbon markets, climate law, and environmental economics, to prepare the next generation of climate experts.

In conclusion, economic shocks will come and go. But the climate crisis is permanent and intensifying. As floods grow more frequent, air pollution worsens, and biodiversity collapses, the cost of inaction grows steeper each year. Trade policy and tax policy must serve, not sabotage our climate goals.

Malaysia must not retreat from climate ambition in the face of tariffs or taxes. We must instead use these shocks to recalibrate our economic tools, reaffirm our global leadership in climate governance, and build a greener, more resilient Malaysia that doesn't trade short-term relief for long-term collapse.

* Mogesh Sababathy is a National Consultative Panel Member to the Ministry of Natural Resources and Environmental Sustainability of Malaysia and a PhD Candidate at Universiti Putra Malaysia (UPM).

title: JENTAYU GROUP EXCHANGES KEY DOCUMENTS FOR 162MW HYDROPOWER PROJECT IN SABAH
bodyText:
Jentayu Sustainables Bhd (JSB) has announced the successful exchange of key documents for its 162-megawatt (MW) run-of-river hydropower project, known as Project Oriole, located at Hulu Sungai Padas, Sipitang.

The documents include the power purchase agreement (PPA) between its subsidiary, Oriole Hydro Padas Sdn Bhd (OHP), and Sabah Electricity Sdn Bhd (SESB), and the engineering, procurement, construction and commissioning (EPCC) contract between OHP and a consortium led by XD Power Transmission Sdn Bhd (XD Power).

JSB executive chairman Datuk Beroz Nikmal Mirdin said Project Oriole is a landmark private sector renewable energy investment for Sabah, aligning with the state€™s commitment to clean, sustainable development to support its economic ambitions.

"This milestone underscores our dedication to advancing Sabah€™s Energy Roadmap 2040 and reflects our confidence in delivering affordable, green infrastructure that benefits both the state and its people," he said in a statement after the documents exchange ceremony at Menara Kinabalu here, today.

Sabah Deputy Chief Minister III Datuk Shahelmey Yahya who is also State Works Minister represented Sabah Chief Minister Datuk Seri Hajiji Noor to witness the exchange of the documents.

OHP was represented its chief executive officer (CEO) Saridah Mohd Dun, SESB was represented by its CEO Mohd Yaakob Jaafar, while the XD Power-led consortium was represented by PT Anhe Konstruksi Indonesia & Anhe Hydropower Engineering Sdn Bhd vice president Lei Yunbiao.

Beroz Nikmal said the project, developed through OHP, is a collaborative effort between JSB, SESB, and Yayasan Sabah, reflecting a shared commitment to ensuring that its long-term benefits are anchored within the state.

Project Oriole is also the first new plant-up PPA signed under the Energy Commission of Sabah€™s (ECoS) framework, marking the state€™s continuous efforts to meet the rising demand for reliable electricity.

The project started in September 2021 and is scheduled to commence commercial operations by June 1, 2029 under a 40-year concession agreement with SESB. Project Oriole will deliver renewable energy at a competitive set tariff of 31.5 sen per kilowatt-hour.

"The long-term tariff positions the project among the most affordable green energy initiatives in the region and highlights Sabah€™s ability to generate cost-effective, clean electricity while further strengthening the state€™s commitment to enhancing energy security," he added.

title: HALAL INDUSTRY AMONG KEY GROWTH DRIVERS IN IMT-GT, BIMP-EAGA
bodyText:
The rapidly-growing halal industry is among nine sectors that can trigger high economic growth in the Indonesia-Malaysia-Thailand Growth Triangle (IMT-GT) and the Brunei Darussalam-Indonesia-Malaysia-Philippines East ASEAN Growth Area (BIMP-EAGA). 

The other key sectors include sustainable agriculture and agribusiness; tourism; green and renewable energy (RE); the digital economy; transport and logistics; palm oil and downstream industries; and Islamic finance, according to International Islamic University Malaysia (IIUM) associate professor of economics, Dr Muhammad Irwan Ariffin.

The marine and fisheries industries are exclusive to the BIMP-EAGA sub-region, he noted.

He said the halal industry in both IMT-GT and BIMP-EAGA sub-regions holds strong global demand for halal food, cosmetics, finance and tourism. "It shares Islamic values across Malaysia, Indonesia, Brunei, southern Thailand and Mindanao, making it a strategic goal to develop IMT-GT as a global halal hub," he told Bernama.

Turning to the agricultural sector, Muhammad Irwan said the combination of vast arable land and a tropical climate drives strong demand for high-value crops, organic farming, agro-processing and agribusiness value chains, which are essential for supporting rural economies.

As for the digital economy, he said increasing internet access in rural areas across the sub-regions has driven the growth of e-commerce, fintech and digital skills development, alongside plans for smart cities and cross-border digital corridors.

"The sub-regions, which are known for their rich biodiversity, natural parks, and cultural heritage, are increasingly focusing on eco-tourism, halal tourism, and cross-border travel circuits, supported by strategic initiatives such as the Visit IMT-GT Year 2023€“2025 campaign,€ he continued. "In the Islamic finance sector, the large Muslim population and underserved rural communities present opportunities for inclusive growth through shariah-compliant financial services that support the development of small and medium enterprises (SMEs) across the regions."

<strong>IMT-GT, BIMP-EAGA align with broader ASEAN goals</strong>

Muhammad Irwan said that while ASEAN€™s broader goals for economic integration and connectivity are guided by the ASEAN Economic Community (AEC) Blueprint 2025 and the Master Plan on ASEAN Connectivity (MPAC) 2025, the IMT-GT and BIMP-EAGA sub-regions can align with these objectives through five key areas.

Firstly, he explained that the sub-regions can support ASEAN's goal to narrow development gaps across the region by focusing on peripheral areas by creating economic opportunities in places often overlooked by national strategies, helping ASEAN advance as a more cohesive and inclusive community.

Secondly, he stated that IMT-GT and BIMP-EAGA can support ASEAN€™s goal of developing seamless transport, trade facilitation, and digital infrastructure, as outlined in MPAC 2025, by investing in cross-border infrastructure like roads, ports, and airports, and by coordinating efforts on border trade facilitation, customs harmonisation, and logistics.

"For example, BIMP-EAGA has launched 210 priority infrastructure projects (PIPs) as of October 2024, including the expansion of border economic zones and connectivity corridors, directly supporting MPAC€™s aim to physically link ASEAN markets," he said.

Muhammad Irwan said IMT-GT and BIMP-EAGA can support ASEAN's goal to increase intra-ASEAN trade and investment by focusing on regional supply chains in agriculture, halal products, tourism, and manufacturing.  For example, IMT-GT€™s Halal Industry Development initiative supports ASEAN€™s bid to become a global halal hub. 

"IMT-GT and BIMP-EAGA also facilitate cross-border investments and SME partnerships, which deepen economic interdependence within ASEAN and integrate border regions into the broader ASEAN market," he added.

He said sub-regions can reinforce ASEAN's mission to have resilience, climate action, and sustainable development through promoting green infrastructure and sustainable tourism, such as UNESCO Geoparks.  

Muhammad Irwan also emphasised that IMT-GT and BIMP-EAGA can support ASEAN's goal to foster cultural ties, mobility, and shared identity by encouraging cross-border travel and joint festivals such as the Visit IMT-GT Year 2023€“2025.

title: ASEAN MUST BE PROACTIVE IN CRAFTING STRATEGIES FOR LONG-TERM PROSPERITY - AMIR HAMZAH
bodyText:
ASEAN must be proactive in crafting strategies that are not only responsive to current challenges but also forward-thinking, setting the stage for long-term prosperity.

Finance Minister II Datuk Seri Amir Hamzah Azizan said that finance ministers, central bank governors, policymakers and regulators collectively bear the immense responsibility of ensuring that the policies and decisions are focused on achieving economic stability, sustainable growth, and financial inclusion.

He emphasised that the focus must not solely be on rebuilding what was lost, but also on seizing new opportunities that align with ASEAN€™s vision for its people.

€œASEAN€™s future is full of promise, thanks to our vibrant economies and growing connections across the region. With a combined GDP (gross domestic product) of over US$3.98 trillion  (US$1=RM4.49), we are already one of the fastest-growing economic regions in the world.

€œWhile challenges such as trade tensions and geopolitical issues lie ahead, our foundation remains strong, and intra-ASEAN trade continues to play a significant role in our shared prosperity. Together, we have the potential to lead in trade, finance, and innovation, as long as we remain adaptable and work hand in hand,€ he said.

Amir Hamzah made these remarks in his welcoming dinner speech in conjunction with the 12th ASEAN Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors€™ Meeting (AFMGM) and related meetings at the Kuala Lumpur Convention Centre (KLCC) here, today.

Moving forward, Amir Hamzah emphasised that ASEAN can strengthen its resilience, stay ahead of global challenges, and ensure lasting prosperity through continued collaboration.

€œIt€™s all about building stronger ties, whether that€™s improving our capital markets, streamlining regulations, or boosting infrastructure.

€œBy facilitating the free movement of goods, services, and capital across borders, we can create a more competitive region, attract investment, and support our businesses,€ he said.

As ASEAN Chair in 2025, Amir Hamzah noted that Malaysia is focused on leading the region in sustainable development and green investments in energy transition, particularly in solar energy, electric vehicles, and green infrastructure.

€œThe future we want to build is one that balances economic growth with environmental sustainability. We understand that economic progress must not come at the expense of our natural resources, and it is crucial that we continue to integrate sustainability into our development strategies,€ he added.

title: Johari calls on palm oil mills to focus on biogas development
bodyText:
PORT DICKSON: A total of 170 out of 446 palm oil mills have installed biogas facilities last year.

This exceeded the National Agrocommodity Policy (NAPC) 2025 target of 155 mills and has contributed to a reduction of greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions by 4.9 million tonnes of carbon dioxide.

Consequently, Plantation and Commodities Minister Datuk Seri Johari Abdul Ghani called on all palm oil millers to prioritise the development of the biogas industry.

"The development of the biogas industry has been proven to provide benefits and added value through the creation of jobs, economic growth, additional income and improved palm waste management â€” ultimately contributing to a better standard of living for rural communities," he said during a visit to the Cenergi Sua Betong Biogas Plant here yesterday.

As the world's second largest palm oil producer, Johari said Malaysia placed emphasis on implementing a circular economy at all stages of palm oil production for better waste management.

"Capturing biomethane from palm oil industry waste, such as palm oil mill effluent (POME), can be used as a renewable energy source for electricity generation."

A total of 63.5 million tonnes of POME was produced in 2022, generating 1.8 billion cubic metres of biogas, which is capable of producing 1.22 gigawatts (GW) of energy per year.

The Sustainable Energy Development Authority allocated a 190MW feed-in tariff quota for this year, covering biogas, biomass and mini hydro projects, as well as 50MW for biogas and 40MW for biomass.

Johari said broader grid connection access was crucial to realise these projects.

He called on Tenaga Nasional Bhd (TNB) to further increase the connection capacity of palm oil mills to the national grid, enabling millers to invest and benefit from the use of palm biomass waste for renewable energy generation.

He said the shift in palm waste management strategy reflected Malaysia's commitment to environmental preservation.

"This is in line with Malaysia's pledge to achieve net zero carbon emissions by 2050, reduce carbon emissions by 45 per cent relative to gross domestic product (GDP) by 2030, and cut methane emissions by 30 per cent," he said.

To encourage more involvement from palm oil industry players, Johari called on millers unfamiliar with this concept to engage with Cenergi SEA Bhd to operate such biogas plants.

"Cenergi has the entire ecosystem in place. This biogas plant, with a capacity of 1.2 megawatts (MW), is operated by just seven people, all locals. They are qualified engineers and workers from the local community," he said.

Cenergi, a subsidiary of UEM Lestra Bhd, is one of the nation's sustainable energy solution providers, specialising in developing Malaysia's green industry, including renewable energy, waste management and green infrastructure.

The company operates 20 biogas plants nationwide, with 12 more under construction, bringing the total electricity generation capacity to 52.8MW and a bio-compressed natural gas capacity to 65,000 million British thermal units.

title: AIIB EYES POLICY REFORMS, PRIVATE CAPITAL TO BOOST INFRASTRUCTURE FINANCING
bodyText:
The Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) is intensifying efforts to make infrastructure projects more financially viable by working closely with governments on policy reforms and encouraging greater private sector participation, especially in green and cross-border projects.

Its acting chief investment officer and director general, public sector clients department region, Rajat Misra, said broader policy interventions are key to addressing the complex risks associated with long-term infrastructure financing.

€œEverybody recognises the need for green infrastructure, green energy, and so on, but typically, long-term finance funding is required.

€œSo, one way is to make it more attractive for private capital to come in,€ he said during the panel discussion titled €˜ASEAN+3 Development Banks: Catalysing Sustainable Investment in ASEAN€™ at the ASEAN Investment Conference (AIC) today.

The AIC is held in conjunction with the 12th ASEAN Finance Ministers€™ and Central Bank Governors€™ Meeting (AFMGM) and related meetings.

Rajat said that to enhance financial feasibility, AIIB not only assists with structuring individual projects but also supports governments in shaping policies that attract private investment.

€œFor example, we introduced something like a climate policy-based loan last year, where we worked with the governments to put in place policies that would attract the private sector to green energy.

€œAnd (we) are just helping them to make projects more bankable, put in place policies, regulatory environment and so on,€ he said.

Meanwhile, the Asian Development Bank€™s (ADB) regional lead economist of the Southeast Asia regional department, James Villafuerte, said the bank aims to bridge the financing gap for ASEAN small and medium enterprises (SMEs) amid the green transition.

He opined that the annual capital requirement for SMEs in the region is estimated to be around US$20 billion (US$1 = RM4.49), yet they could only raise about US$2 billion, leaving a 90 per cent financing gap.

€œAt ADB, we think that the SME transition in the region has a few challenges, and they really need to scale out their activities, particularly in areas such as energy efficiency and waste management.

€œAdditionally, they must play an active role in the green transition,€ he said.

To address these issues, Villafuerte said the ADB would collaborate with banks to act as intermediaries and channel funds to SMEs to help them meet these sustainability and growth objectives.
